In October 1971, Frank Zappa & The Mothers of Invention played two shows in one 
night at New York CityÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Carnegie Hall. For the first time ever, those recordings are available for pre-order as a four-disc set. The album, Carnegie Hall, celebrates that night's marathon -- two shows (7:30 and 11:30 p.m.) with ticket prices ranging from $3.50 to $6 -- featuring Zappa (lead guitar, vocals) with Mark Volman (vocals, percussion), Howard Kaylan (vocals), Ian Underwood (keyboards, alto sax), Don Preston (keyboards, gong), Jim Pons (bass, vocals) and Aynsley Dunbar (drums).

Promoter Ron Delsener, who had to convince the venueÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s booker that Zappa was Ã¢â‚¬Å“a very accomplished classical musician of several wind instruments like the cello, viola and harp,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ says Ã¢â‚¬Å“enjoy genius and smile, Frank is smilinÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ at you.Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½

The four-disc set launches with The Persuasions, an a cappella group whose first album was recorded by Zappa in 1970.
